events.text_segment:
With a convulsive motion, he tore away the ministerial band from before his breast. It was revealed! But it were irreverent to describe that revelation. For an instant, the gaze of the horror-stricken multitude was concentred on the ghastly miracle; while the minister stood, with a flush of triumph in his face, as one who, in the crisis of acutest pain, had won a victory. Then, down he sank upon the scaffold! Hester partly raised him, and supported his head against her bosom. Old Roger Chillingworth knelt down beside him, with a blank, dull countenance, out of which the life seemed to have departed.
“Thou hast escaped me!” he repeated more than once. “Thou hast escaped me!”
“May God forgive thee!” said the minister. “Thou, too, hast deeply sinned!”
He withdrew his dying eyes from the old man, and fixed them on the woman and the child.
“My little Pearl,” said he, feebly,—and there was a sweet and gentle smile over his face, as of a spirit sinking into deep repose; nay, now that the burden was removed, it seemed almost as if he would be sportive with the child,—“dear little Pearl, wilt thou kiss me now? Thou wouldst not, yonder, in the forest! But now thou wilt?”
Pearl kissed his lips. A spell was broken. The great scene of grief, in which the wild infant bore a part, had developed all her sympathies; and as her tears fell upon her father’s cheek, they were the pledge that she would grow up amid human joy and sorrow, nor forever do battle with the world, but be a woman in it. Towards her mother, too, Pearl’s errand as a messenger of anguish was all fulfilled.
“Hester,” said the clergyman, “farewell!”
“Shall we not meet again?” whispered she, bending her face down close to his. “Shall we not spend our immortal life together? Surely, surely, we have ransomed one another, with all this woe! Thou lookest far into eternity, with those bright dying eyes! Then tell me what thou seest?”
“Hush, Hester, hush!” said he, with tremulous solemnity. “The law we broke!—the sin here so awfully revealed!—let these alone be in thy thoughts! I fear! I fear! It may be, that, when we forgot our God,—when we violated our reverence each for the other’s soul,—it was thenceforth vain to hope that we could meet hereafter, in an everlasting and pure reunion. God knows; and He is merciful! He hath proved his mercy, most of all, in my afflictions. By giving me this burning torture to bear upon my breast! By sending yonder dark and terrible old man, to keep the torture always at red-heat! By bringing me hither, to die this death of triumphant ignominy before the people! Had either of these agonies been wanting, I had been lost forever! Praised be his name! His will be done! Farewell!”
That final word came forth with the minister’s expiring breath. The multitude, silent till then, broke out in a strange, deep voice of awe and wonder, which could not as yet find utterance, save in this murmur that rolled so heavily after the departed spirit.

events.title: Diverse Interpretations of Dimmesdale's Scaffold Revelation
detailed_summary: Following Reverend Mr. Dimmesdale's public appearance on the scaffold, varying accounts emerged among the townspeople regarding what they had witnessed.
A significant portion of the spectators asserted they had seen a scarlet letter, identical to the one Hester Prynne wore, physically marked on the minister's chest.

Numerous theories, all speculative, arose concerning the origin of this mark: some believed Dimmesdale had inflicted it upon himself as a form of penance starting when Hester first received her sentence; others proposed that Roger Chillingworth, using his knowledge of dark arts and medicines, had caused it to appear much later.

A third group, considering the minister's sensitive nature and the profound connection between his spirit and body, suggested the symbol was the physical manifestation of his deep remorse, a divine judgment made visible.
The narrator presents these differing explanations, leaving the reader to decide which is most plausible.
Conversely, certain individuals who claimed to have observed the entire event intently denied that any mark whatsoever was present on Dimmesdale's breast.
According to their testimony, Dimmesdale's dying words did not acknowledge or even subtly suggest any personal involvement in the sin for which Hester Prynne was punished.

These witnesses believed that the minister, aware of his impending death and his revered status, intended his demise in the arms of Hester to be a symbolic lesson about the inadequacy of human righteousness before God.
They interpreted his final act as a parable meant to convey that all individuals are inherently sinful and that true holiness is found in recognizing divine mercy, rather than in human achievements.

The narrator, however, critically views this latter interpretation as an example of how devoted friends, particularly those of a clergyman, might stubbornly defend his reputation even when faced with compelling evidence of his transgressions.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: AFTER many days, when time sufficed for the people to arrange their thoughts in reference to the foregoing scene, there was more than one account of what had been witnessed on the scaffold.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Without disputing a truth so momentous, we must be allowed to consider this version of Mr. Dimmesdale’s story as only an instance of that stubborn fidelity with which a man’s friends—and especially a clergyman’s—will sometimes uphold his character, when proofs, clear as the mid-day sunshine on the scarlet letter, establish him a false and sin-stained creature of the dust.

events.text_segment:
AFTER many days, when time sufficed for the people to arrange their thoughts in reference to the foregoing scene, there was more than one account of what had been witnessed on the scaffold.
Most of the spectators testified to having seen, on the breast of the unhappy minister, a SCARLET LETTER—the very semblance of that worn by Hester Prynne—imprinted in the flesh. As regarded its origin, there were various explanations, all of which must necessarily have been conjectural. Some affirmed that the Reverend Mr. Dimmesdale, on the very day when Hester Prynne first wore her ignominious badge, had begun a course of penance,—which he afterwards, in so many futile methods, followed out,—by inflicting a hideous torture on himself. Others contended that the stigma had not been produced until a long time subsequent, when old Roger Chillingworth, being a potent necromancer, had caused it to appear, through the agency of magic and poisonous drugs. Others, again,—and those best able to appreciate the minister’s peculiar sensibility, and the wonderful operation of his spirit upon the body,—whispered their belief, that the awful symbol was the effect of the ever-active tooth of remorse, gnawing from the inmost heart outwardly, and at last manifesting Heaven’s dreadful judgment by the visible presence of the letter. The reader may choose among these theories. We have thrown all the light we could acquire upon the portent, and would gladly, now that it has done its office, erase its deep print out of our own brain; where long meditation has fixed it in very undesirable distinctness.
It is singular, nevertheless, that certain persons, who were spectators of the whole scene, and professed never once to have removed their eyes from the Reverend Mr. Dimmesdale, denied that there was any mark whatever on his breast, more than on a new-born infant’s. Neither, by their report, had his dying words acknowledged, nor even remotely implied, any, the slightest connection, on his part, with the guilt for which Hester Prynne had so long worn the scarlet letter. According to these highly respectable witnesses, the minister, conscious that he was dying,—conscious, also, that the reverence of the multitude placed him already among saints and angels,—had desired, by yielding up his breath in the arms of that fallen woman, to express to the world how utterly nugatory is the choicest of man’s own righteousness. After exhausting life in his efforts for mankind’s spiritual good, he had made the manner of his death a parable, in order to impress on his admirers the mighty and mournful lesson, that, in the view of Infinite Purity, we are sinners all alike. It was to teach them, that the holiest among us has but attained so far above his fellows as to discern more clearly the Mercy which looks down, and repudiate more utterly the phantom of human merit, which would look aspiringly upward. Without disputing a truth so momentous, we must be allowed to consider this version of Mr. Dimmesdale’s story as only an instance of that stubborn fidelity with which a man’s friends—and especially a clergyman’s—will sometimes uphold his character, when proofs, clear as the mid-day sunshine on the scarlet letter, establish him a false and sin-stained creature of the dust.

According to these highly respectable witnesses, the minister, conscious that he was dying—conscious, also, that the reverence of the multitude placed him already among saints and angels—had desired, by yielding up his breath in the arms of that fallen woman, to express to the world how utterly nugatory is the choicest of man's own righteousness. After exhausting life in his efforts for mankind's spiritual good, he had made the manner of his death a parable, in order to impress on his admirers the mighty and mournful lesson, that, in the view of Infinite Purity, we are sinners all alike. It was to teach them, that the holiest among us has but attained so far above his fellows as to discern more clearly the Mercy which looks down, and repudiate more utterly the phantom of human merit, which would look aspiringly upward.

Without disputing a truth so momentous, we must be allowed to consider this version of Mr. Dimmesdale's story as only an instance of that stubborn fidelity with which a man's friends—and especially a clergyman's—will sometimes uphold his character, when proofs, clear as the mid-day sunshine on the scarlet letter, establish him a false and sin-stained creature of the dust.

events.title: The Narrator's Corroboration and the Story's Moral Imperative
detailed_summary: The narrator asserts that their account is primarily based on an old manuscript, compiled from the spoken testimonies of individuals who either knew Hester Prynne personally or had heard her story from those who lived during that time.
This source material is presented as fully supporting the interpretation of events and character motivations detailed in the preceding narrative, particularly concerning Dimmesdale's guilt.
From the minister's tragic life experiences, the narrator distills a singular, emphatic moral lesson.

This central moral exhorts individuals to live authentically, to be truthful about their inner selves, and to openly reveal to the world, if not their most egregious faults, then at least some characteristic that might allow others to perceive their true nature.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The authority which we have chiefly followed,—a manuscript of old date, drawn up from the verbal testimony of individuals, some of whom had known Hester Prynne, while others had heard the tale from contemporary witnesses,—fully confirms the view taken in the foregoing pages.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Among many morals which press upon us from the poor minister’s miserable experience, we put only this into a sentence:—“Be true! Be true! Be true! Show freely to the world, if not your worst, yet some trait whereby the worst may be inferred!”

**text_segment**: The authority which we have chiefly followed,—a manuscript of old date, drawn up from the verbal testimony of individuals, some of whom had known Hester Prynne, while others had heard the tale from contemporary witnesses,—fully confirms the view taken in the foregoing pages. Show freely to the world, if not your worst, yet some trait whereby the worst may be inferred!"

Nothing was more remarkable than the change which took place, almost immediately after Mr. Dimmesdale's death, in the appearance and demeanor of the old man known as Roger Chillingworth. All his strength and energy—all his vital and intellectual force—seemed at once to desert him; insomuch that he positively withered up, shrivelled away, and almost vanished from mortal sight, like an uprooted weed that lies wilting in the sun. This unhappy man had made the very principle of his life to consist in the pursuit and systematic exercise of revenge; and when, by its completest triumph and consummation, that evil principle was left with no further material to support it,—when, in short, there was no more Devil's work on earth for him to do, it only remained for the unhumanized mortal to betake himself whither his Master would find him tasks enough, and pay him his wages duly.

events.title: Chillingworth's Decline and the Philosophical Nature of Hate
detailed_summary: A profound and swift alteration occurred in Roger Chillingworth's appearance and behavior almost immediately following Reverend Mr. Dimmesdale's death.

All his physical strength, energy, and intellectual vigor seemed to desert him instantly, leading him to physically wither and diminish, almost vanishing like a plant uprooted and left to die in the sun.
This unfortunate man had centered his entire existence on the methodical pursuit and execution of revenge against Dimmesdale.

When this driving passion reached its ultimate fulfillment with Dimmesdale's demise, the evil principle that fueled Chillingworth was left without a target, effectively leaving him without a purpose for living.
The narrator then engages in a philosophical consideration of whether hatred and love might, at their core, be the same emotion.
It is argued that both passions, in their most developed forms, necessitate a high degree of intimacy and deep understanding of another person's heart.
Furthermore, each makes one individual reliant on another for emotional and spiritual sustenance.
The loss of the object of passion, whether of love or hate, leaves the individual feeling forlorn and desolate.
From this philosophical standpoint, the two emotions appear essentially identical, distinguished only by their perceived aura—one seen in a heavenly light, the other in a dark and ominous glow.

The narrator speculates that in the afterlife, Chillingworth and Dimmesdale, having been mutual victims on earth, might unknowingly find their deep-seated hatred and animosity transformed into a pure and valuable love.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Nothing was more remarkable than the change which took place, almost immediately after Mr. Dimmesdale’s death, in the appearance and demeanor of the old man known as Roger Chillingworth.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: In the spiritual world, the old physician and the minister—mutual victims as they have been—may, unawares, have found their earthly stock of hatred and antipathy transmuted into golden love.

events.text_segment: Nothing was more remarkable than the change which took place, almost immediately after Mr. Dimmesdale’s death, in the appearance and demeanor of the old man known as Roger Chillingworth. All his strength and energy—all his vital and intellectual force—seemed at once to desert him; insomuch that he positively withered up, shrivelled away, and almost vanished from mortal sight, like an uprooted weed that lies wilting in the sun. This unhappy man had made the very principle of his life to consist in the pursuit and systematic exercise of revenge; and when, by its completest triumph and consummation, that evil principle was left with no further material to support it, when, in short, there was no more Devil’s work on earth for him to do, it only remained for the unhumanized mortal to betake himself whither his Master would find him tasks enough, and pay him his wages duly. But, to all these shadowy beings, so long our near acquaintances,—as well Roger Chillingworth as his companions,—we would fain be merciful. It is a curious subject of observation and inquiry, whether hatred and love be not the same thing at bottom. Each, in its utmost development, supposes a high degree of intimacy and heart-knowledge; each renders one individual dependent for the food of his affections and spiritual life upon another; each leaves the passionate lover, or the no less passionate hater, forlorn and desolate by the withdrawal of his subject. Philosophically considered, therefore, the two passions seem essentially the same, except that one happens to be seen in a celestial radiance, and the other in a dusky and lurid glow. In the spiritual world, the old physician and the minister—mutual victims as they have been—may, unawares, have found their earthly stock of hatred and antipathy transmuted into golden love.

events.title: Pearl's Unexpected Fortune and Enigmatic Departure
detailed_summary: The narrator shifts focus from philosophical reflections to convey a practical piece of information regarding the aftermath of Roger Chillingworth's life.
Chillingworth died within the year following Reverend Mr. Dimmesdale's passing.

Through his last will and testament, for which Governor Bellingham and the Reverend Mr. Wilson served as executors, Chillingworth bequeathed a very substantial amount of property, located both in New England and in England, to little Pearl, Hester Prynne's daughter.
This inheritance transformed Pearl—once regarded as an elfin and even demonic child—into the most affluent heiress of her era in the New World.
The narrator suggests that this significant change in fortune likely led to a considerable alteration in how the public perceived Pearl.

It is speculated that had Hester and Pearl remained in the community, Pearl, upon reaching a marriageable age, might have integrated her unique lineage with that of one of the most devout Puritan families.
However, not long after the physician's death, Hester, the wearer of the scarlet letter, disappeared from the town, taking Pearl with her.

Over a span of many years, despite occasional, indistinct rumors reaching New England from across the ocean—likened to unidentified driftwood bearing initials—no definitively authentic news of Hester and Pearl was ever received.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Leaving this discussion apart, we have a matter of business to communicate to the reader.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: For many years, though a vague report would now and then find its way across the sea,—like a shapeless piece of drift-wood tost ashore, with the initials of a name upon it,—yet no tidings of them unquestionably authentic were received.

events.text_segment:
Leaving this discussion apart, we have a matter of business to communicate to the reader. At old Roger Chillingworth’s decease, (which took place within the year,) and by his last will and testament, of which Governor Bellingham and the Reverend Mr. Wilson were executors, he bequeathed a very considerable amount of property, both here and in England, to little Pearl, the daughter of Hester Prynne.
So Pearl—the elf-child,—the demon offspring, as some people, up to that epoch, persisted in considering her,—became the richest heiress of her day, in the New World. Not improbably, this circumstance wrought a very material change in the public estimation; and, had the mother and child remained here, little Pearl, at a marriageable period of life, might have mingled her wild blood with the lineage of the devoutest Puritan among them all. But, in no long time after the physician’s death, the wearer of the scarlet letter disappeared, and Pearl along with her. For many years, though a vague report would now and then find its way across the sea,—like a shapeless piece of drift-wood tost ashore, with the initials of a name upon it,—yet no tidings of them unquestionably authentic were received.

events.title: The Enduring Legend and Hester's Return to the Abandoned Cottage
detailed_summary: Over time, the narrative of the scarlet letter evolved into a legendary tale within the community.
The scaffold, the site of the minister's death, and the seaside cottage where Hester Prynne had lived, continued to hold a powerful and solemn significance.
One afternoon, after many years had passed, some children playing near Hester's long-abandoned cottage observed a tall woman, clad in a gray robe, approaching its door.
The cottage had remained unopened throughout all the intervening years.
The woman managed to enter, whether by unlocking it, the decaying structure giving way, or as if she glided ethereally through any physical impediments.

Upon reaching the threshold, she paused and turned slightly, as if the prospect of re-entering, alone and so changed, the home that had witnessed such an intense period of her former life was almost too desolate and overwhelming for her to bear.
This moment of hesitation, though brief, was sufficient to reveal the presence of a scarlet letter upon her chest.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The story of the scarlet letter grew into a legend.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But her hesitation was only for an instant, though long enough to display a scarlet letter on her breast.

events.text_segment:
The story of the scarlet letter grew into a legend. Its spell, however, was still potent, and kept the scaffold awful where the poor minister had died, and likewise the cottage by the sea-shore, where Hester Prynne had dwelt. Near this latter spot, one afternoon, some children were at play, when they beheld a tall woman, in a gray robe, approach the cottage-door. In all those years it had never once been opened; but either she unlocked it, or the decaying wood and iron yielded to her hand, or she glided shadow-like through these impediments,—and, at all events, went in.
On the threshold she paused,—turned partly round,—for, perchance, the idea of entering all alone, and all so changed, the home of so intense a former life, was more dreary and desolate than even she could bear. But her hesitation was only for an instant, though long enough to display a scarlet letter on her breast.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
**text_segment**: The story of the scarlet letter grew into a legend. The spot where Dimmesdale had stood was one of the most curious features in the legend. For many years it was a locality of awe. It was said that the grass had refused to grow under the unhallowed footsteps of the minister. The scaffold, too, the platform of pillory, was a portion of a penal machine which was held to have been a mode of punishment long before, in the primitive ages of Puritan policy. In the lapse of the toilsome, thoughtful, and self-devoted years that made up Hester's life, the scarlet letter ceased to be a stigma which attracted the world's scorn and bitterness, and became a type of something to be sorrowed over, and looked upon with awe, yet with reverence too.

Many people refused to interpret the scarlet A by its original signification. According to these highly respectable witnesses, the letter was not of earthly red, but of a dusky hue, and was meant to be worn for the remainder of her mortal state. In the view of such an interpretation, Hester Prynne, with a mind of native courage and activity, had conferred a real service on the community.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The story of the scarlet letter grew into a legend. Throughout Salem, whispers of Hester Prynne's punishment and resilience spread from generation to generation. The embroidered "A" she wore became more than a symbol of shame—it transformed into a mark of strength and dignity in the community's collective memory. Children would point when she passed, both in awe and curiosity. The elderly recalled her story with a mixture of judgment and grudging respect for how she bore her burden.

As years passed, the meaning of the scarlet letter evolved in public consciousness. What once represented adultery came to signify ability, artistry, and even a kind of admirable fortitude. Hester's quiet dignity in facing her punishment and her unwavering dedication to her daughter Pearl became central to how her story was told and retold, embedding itself into the moral fabric of the town long after the original participants had passed away.

events.title: Hester's Final Years: Counsel, Distant Connection to Pearl, and Shared Legacy
detailed_summary: Indeed, Hester Prynne had come back and had voluntarily resumed wearing the scarlet letter, the symbol of her past shame.
The fate of Pearl, who would now have been a young woman, remained unknown to the community; whether she was alive, had found happiness, or had passed away young was a matter of speculation.
However, subtle indications suggested that Pearl was alive and maintained a loving, albeit distant, relationship with her mother.

These signs included the arrival of letters bearing aristocratic seals unfamiliar to English heraldry, and the presence in Hester's cottage of comfortable and luxurious items that Hester herself did not use, implying they were gifts purchased by wealth and sent with affection.

Once, Hester was observed embroidering a baby garment with such lavish and rich design that it would have caused a public outcry if an infant so dressed had been seen in their plainly adorned community, hinting at Pearl's potential motherhood.

Local gossip, later supported by the investigations of Mr. Surveyor Pue and his successors, maintained that Pearl was not only alive but also happily married and mindful of her mother, wishing she could have Hester by her side.
Hester, however, found a more profound and meaningful existence in New England, the location of her past sin and sorrow, which she now chose as the place for her ongoing penitence.
She resumed wearing the scarlet letter of her own accord, never taking it off again.

Over the many years of her diligent, reflective, and selfless life, the meaning of the scarlet letter transformed in the community's perception; it ceased to be a mark inviting scorn and bitterness, instead becoming a symbol evoking sorrow, awe, and reverence.

As Hester Prynne lived without selfish motivations or concern for personal benefit, people, particularly women facing emotional distress, romantic troubles, or feelings of being wronged or sinful, sought her counsel and comfort at her cottage.
Hester offered them solace and advice to the best of her ability.

She also shared her strong belief that a brighter future would eventually arrive, in God's own time, when a new understanding would emerge to establish the relationship between men and women on a more secure foundation of mutual happiness.

Earlier in her life, Hester had imagined she might be destined to be the prophetess of this new truth, but she had long since accepted that such a divine mission could not be entrusted to a woman marked by sin, burdened by shame, or weighed down by lifelong sorrow.

She envisioned the herald of this future revelation as a woman who was indeed noble, pure, and beautiful, and whose wisdom came not from sorrow but from joy, demonstrating through a successful life how sacred love should lead to happiness.

After many more years, a new grave was prepared for Hester near an old, sunken one in the burial ground by King’s Chapel, close to Dimmesdale's, yet with a distinct space between them, as if their remains should not intermingle.
However, a single tombstone served for both.

This simple slate slab, unlike the surrounding ornate monuments, featured an engraved escutcheon with a heraldic device that could serve as a motto for the entire legend: 'On a field, sable, the letter A, gules' – a dark background with a scarlet letter A, its somberness relieved by a single, ever-glowing point of light that was itself gloomier than shadow.

events.text_segment:
And Hester Prynne had returned, and taken up her long-forsaken shame! But where was little Pearl? If still alive, she must now have been in the flush and bloom of early womanhood. None knew—nor ever learned, with the fulness of perfect certainty—whether the elf-child had gone thus untimely to a maiden grave; or whether her wild, rich nature had been softened and subdued, and made capable of a woman’s gentle happiness. But, through the remainder of Hester’s life, there were indications that the recluse of the scarlet letter was the object of love and interest with some inhabitant of another land. Letters came, with armorial seals upon them, though of bearings unknown to English heraldry. In the cottage there were articles of comfort and luxury such as Hester never cared to use, but which only wealth could have purchased, and affection have imagined for her. There were trifles, too, little ornaments, beautiful tokens of a continual remembrance, that must have been wrought by delicate fingers, at the impulse of a fond heart. And, once, Hester was seen embroidering a baby-garment, with such a lavish richness of golden fancy as would have raised a public tumult, had any infant, thus apparelled, been shown to our sober-hued community.
In fine, the gossips of that day believed,—and Mr. Surveyor Pue, who made investigations a century later, believed,—and one of his recent successors in office, moreover, faithfully believes,—that Pearl was not only alive, but married, and happy, and mindful of her mother, and that she would most joyfully have entertained that sad and lonely mother at her fireside.
But there was a more real life for Hester Prynne here, in New England, than in that unknown region where Pearl had found a home. Here had been her sin; here, her sorrow; and here was yet to be her penitence. She had returned, therefore, and resumed,—of her own free will, for not the sternest magistrate of that iron period would have imposed it,—resumed the symbol of which we have related so dark a tale. Never afterwards did it quit her bosom. But, in the lapse of the toilsome, thoughtful, and self-devoted years that made up Hester’s life, the scarlet letter ceased to be a stigma which attracted the world’s scorn and bitterness, and became a type of something to be sorrowed over, and looked upon with awe, yet with reverence too. And, as Hester Prynne had no selfish ends, nor lived in any measure for her own profit and enjoyment, people brought all their sorrows and perplexities, and besought her counsel, as one who had herself gone through a mighty trouble. Women, more especially,—in the continually recurring trials of wounded, wasted, wronged, misplaced, or erring and sinful passion,—or with the dreary burden of a heart unyielded, because unvalued and unsought,—came to Hester’s cottage, demanding why they were so wretched, and what the remedy! Hester comforted and counselled them as best she might. She assured them, too, of her firm belief, that, at some brighter period, when the world should have grown ripe for it, in Heaven’s own time, a new truth would be revealed, in order to establish the whole relation between man and woman on a surer ground of mutual happiness. Earlier in life, Hester had vainly imagined that she herself might be the destined prophetess, but had long since recognized the impossibility that any mission of divine and mysterious truth should be confided to a woman stained with sin, bowed down with shame, or even burdened with a life-long sorrow. The angel and apostle of the coming revelation must be a woman, indeed, but lofty, pure, and beautiful; and wise, moreover, not through dusky grief, but the ethereal medium of joy; and showing how sacred love should make us happy, by the truest test of a life successful to such an end!
So said Hester Prynne, and glanced her sad eyes downward at the scarlet letter. And, after many, many years, a new grave was delved, near an old and sunken one, in that burial-ground beside which King’s Chapel has since been built. It was near that old and sunken grave, yet with a space between, as if the dust of the two sleepers had no right to mingle. Yet one tombstone served for both. All around, there were monuments carved with armorial bearings; and on this simple slab of slate—as the curious investigator may still discern, and perplex himself with the purport—there appeared the semblance of an engraved escutcheon. It bore a device, a herald’s wording of which might serve for a motto and brief description of our now concluded legend; so sombre is it, and relieved only by one ever-glowing point of light gloomier than the shadow:—“On a field, sable, the letter A, gules.”

And Hester Prynne had returned, and taken up her long-forsaken shame! But it was no longer as a shame that she wore the scarlet letter upon her bosom. Many years had passed since she had dwelt within the little cottage on the outskirts of the town, where now she had come again to dwell.

Of Pearl, little was certainly known. Whether the fair child had gone to a premature grave, or whether her wild, rich nature had been softened and subdued, and made capable of a woman's gentle happiness, no tidings reached the people of the settlement. Yet there were indications that all was well with her, and that she had not forgotten her mother. Letters came, with armorial seals, unknown to English heraldry; and, in the cottage, there were articles of comfort and luxury, such as Hester never cared to use, but which only wealth could have purchased, and affection have imagined for her. There were trifles, too, little ornaments, beautiful tokens of a continual remembrance, that must have been wrought by delicate fingers, at the impulse of a fond heart.

Once, the gossips of the town beheld Hester Prynne, with a work of infant's apparel in her hands, fashioning it with such lavish embroidery as would have raised a public tumult, had any infant thus apparelled been shown to our sober-hued community. The old magistrates and church-elders whispered that such a child, so bedizened, could only be destined for the courts of far-off monarchs.

It was believed—and Mr. Surveyor Pue, who made investigations a century later, confirmed it—that Pearl was not only alive, but married, and happy, and mindful of her mother; and that she would most joyfully have entertained that sad and lonely mother at her fireside.

But there was a more real life for Hester Prynne here, in New England, than in that unknown region where Pearl had found a home. Here had been her sin; here, her sorrow; and here was yet to be her penitence. She had returned, therefore, and resumed—of her own free will, for not the sternest magistrate of that iron period would have imposed it—resumed the symbol of which we have related so dark a tale. Never afterwards did it quit her bosom.

But, in the lapse of the toilsome, thoughtful, and self-devoted years that made up Hester's life, the scarlet letter ceased to be a stigma which attracted the world's scorn and bitterness, and became a type of something to be sorrowed over, and looked upon with awe, yet with reverence too. And, as Hester Prynne had no selfish ends, nor lived in any measure for her own profit and enjoyment, people brought all their sorrows and perplexities, and besought her counsel, as one who had herself gone through a mighty trouble. And Hester Prynne had returned, and taken up her long-forsaken shame! But it was not the same town nor the same scarlet letter that had known her in former years. The letter was the symbol of her calling. Such helpfulness was found in her,—so much power to do, and power to sympathize,—that many people refused to interpret the scarlet A by its original signification. They said that it meant Able; so strong was Hester Prynne, with a woman's strength.

Many years, indeed, had passed since Hester's return. It was little Pearl's story that remained untold. No intelligence had ever come concerning her. Whether living or dead, none could tell. In those times of rigid authority, the disappearance of a member of the community would have been an occasion of inquiry; but Pearl had vanished when all minds were engrossed by the terrible pestilence that devastated New England. She had gone, and had never come back.
